sn16.1:4.2: “Mendicants, Kassapa is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment.
sn16.1:4.3: He doesn’t try to get hold of a robe in an improper way.
sn16.1:4.4: He doesn’t get upset if he doesn’t get a robe.
sn16.1:4.5: And if he does get a robe, he uses it untied, unstupefied, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
sn16.1:5.1: Kassapa is content with any kind of alms-food …
sn16.1:6.1: Kassapa is content with any kind of lodging …
sn16.1:7.1: Kassapa is content with any kind of medicinal requisites and supports for the sick …
sn16.1:8.1: So you should train like this:
sn16.1:8.2: ‘We will be content with any kind of robe, and praise such contentment.
sn16.1:8.3: We won’t try to get hold of a robe in an improper way.
sn16.1:8.4: We won’t get upset if we don’t get a robe.
sn16.1:8.5: And if we do get a robe, we’ll use it untied, unstupefied, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.’
sn16.1:8.6: (All should be treated the same way.)
sn16.1:9.1: ‘We will be content with any kind of alms-food …’
sn16.1:9.2: ‘We will be content with any kind of lodging …’
sn16.1:9.3: ‘We will be content with any kind of medicinal requisites and supports for the sick …’
sn16.1:9.7: I will exhort you with the example of Kassapa or someone like him. You should practice accordingly.”
